Additional and more details regarding emergency responses has been established in the EAP and would be under frequent revision, as considered appropriate. Although the EAP is a comprehensive document, it is not intended to replace judgement; this notion is also trained on at BGF by way of the acknowledgement of Behavior Based Safety training to employees. Any employee encountering a situation which threaten life or property may be required to decide appropriate immediate actions. Life must be protected before property in these instances.

Being a newly constructed site and company registered a few years prior to the start of its construction site in Humacao, the BGF facility has had no accidents meeting the rules accident reporting criteria. Furthermore, BGF is currently addressing action items resulting from the process hazards analysis (PHA) study during the HAZOP efforts conducted for the facility. Additional process safeguards, changes to equipment and operating procedures as well as risk reduction measures were recommended. Each these recommendations are being carefully studied by BGF to ensure that potential hazards are adequately address and site operations does not create other hazards or complications.

These actions must be left to emergency services who have the necessary training, equipment, and experience to do so.
	All mechanical failures will be immediately reported to area emergency leaders or coordinators for immediate attention. If a main supply line is affected designated personnel will redirect flow to available lines. Mechanical failures of trucks and similar vehicles would also be reported to emergency leaders or coordinators, who will decide whether the unit should be removed from operations or will entail major repairs.
	In the event of a power outage, the Emergency Response Leader on duty will instruct employees to take the correct course of action depending upon the anticipated length of the outage.  
	In the event of a natural disaster affecting the facility, such as a hurricane, flood, earthquake or other, the facilitys personnel will activate the alarm or evacuation signal. Once personnel have been evacuated, persons will be prohibited from entering the facility for the duration of the natural disaster. Once the disaster is over, the Emergency Response team will determine the severity of the damage caused by the disaster and then begin with the necessary cleaning and/or repair work.
	To minimize the damage caused by earthquakes, employees must prepare the facility in the event of an earthquake: anchor machinery and equipment, brace suspended equipment, store heavy objects near the ground, secure breakable items and ensure materials are safely stored. During an earthquake, all employees at the facility must keep away from overhead pipelines, power lines, utility poles, trees, and heavy equipment/objects. As BGF operations involves management of landfill gas, identification of leaks is critical at the facility. As part of site operations, pressure changes are meticulously monitored throughout the industrial process as it may indicate a potential gas leak. For such purposes equipment and processes have been designed in accordance with PR Building Code, NPFA Guidelines, and other applicable codes and guidelines. Isolation valves have been provided throughout the process to better control and respond to any potential gas leak.

In terms of emergency preparedness, BGF has prepared and implemented procedures for the management of emergencies that may arise because of fires, explosions, natural disasters or leakage of landfill gas or its components that may threaten public health and safety or the environment. BFG has integrated an emergency organizational hierarchy to ensure an effective risk management onsite during incidents that require immediate response. Biomass Green Fuels LLC (BGF) operates a landfill gas recovery, cleaning, and compression facility, located in the southeastern portion of the Humacao Landfill owned and operated by the El Coqui Landfill Company, LLC (ECL). The BGF site is located on the State Road PR-923, Km. 1.7, Buena Vista Ward in Humacao, Puerto Rico and it is bound by the North, West and South by the operations of ECL and to the East by the State Road PR-923 and Palacios del Mar residential development. The primary operations at the BGF facility correspond to processes of converting the LFG to Renewable Natural Gas (RNG) to be commercialized gases.

As an introductory statement, the Landfill Gas (LFG) is a product derived from the breakdown or biodegradation of the organic matter of the landfill system under anaerobic conditions. The raw LFG generated by the landfill system will be recovered and transported, through pipelines, to the conversion plant to be processed and converted to RNG and renewable CO2 (RCO2). The process involves the removal of Sulphur compounds, CO2, and organic and inorganic compounds to manufacture RNG with a high energy content is to be produced as well as to produce electric power that will meet the demand of the site and that of the ECL. 

 The LFG, then, will be refined, compressed, and liquefied until reaching a liquid state to be able to dispatch as RNG fuel. As a landfill gas refinery plant, the main substance used and/or handled at the facility is methane gas in form of liquified RNG. The maximum quantity of gas onsite is expected to be 217,371 pounds stored in six isotank containers, each one provided with level, pressure and temperature measurement technology and alarm system to promptly identify any leak and helping prevent costly product loss and potential safety incidents.
